Amnesty International criticizes human rights abuses 
   Pyongyang, March 2 (KCNA) -- The Amnesty International recently decided to conduct widespread campaign in protest against the South Korean authority's abuses of human rights.   It said that it would urge the South Korean "government" to release all the prisoners of conscience, set up a public human rights organization and guarantee the right to labor.   It also said that, for this purpose, its chapters in all countries would pay protest visits to South Korean embassies and send letters of protest to them for 3 months from March as a campaign to put international pressure upon the South Korean regime.

Arms buildup in S.Korea
     Pyongyang, March 2 (KCNA) -- The South Korean authorities had purchased 9.5 billion dollars worth of military hardware from the United States from 1993 to 1997, according to a news report.   This fact was disclosed by a recent issue of a U.S. monthly news magazine.   The newly purchased weapons include bodies of multi-stage rocket systems, stinger anti-air missiles and harpoon anti-warship missiles.

Congratulations on day of proclamation
    Pyongyang, March 2 (KCNA) -- President Kim Yong Nam of the Presidium of the Supreme People's Assembly of the DPRK sent today a message of greetings to Moammer al-Gaddafi, leader of the September 1st Revolution of the Socialist People's Libyan Arab Jamahiriya, on the occasion of the 22nd anniversary of the proclamation of Jamahiriya in Libya.   Expressing the belief that friendly and cooperative relations between the two countries forged in the anti-imperialist joint struggle for independence would grow stronger, the message wished the head of state and the people of Libya greater success in their efforts to build a new free and prosperous Libya.
